section.heading: Argument of Ward L. Johnson, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in 76-879, Zablocki against Redhail.
Mr. Johnson, I think you may proceed when you are ready.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
This a direct appeal from the District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, which declared a Wisconsin State Statute imposing a marriage, certain marriage requirement unconstitutional.
The facts in this case are not in dispute.
The named plaintiff Redhail, six years ago approximately fathered a baby girl out of wedlock.
At that time he was in high school.
Two years subsequent he applied for permission to marry to the county clerk of Milwaukee county of the State of Wisconsin, because of a marriage requirement, the clerk denied him a license.

The requirement that was the basis for the denial by the county clerk was that a person who has minor children, not in his custody to whom he has an obligation to support must get permission from a Court to marry.
In Mr. Redhail's case he had never been married.

We suspect the bulk of the cases arising where there has been -- where there is a requirement to get a Court's permission to marry are those cases involving people who have been divorced, who have been married before.

At this point Mr. Redhail filed a complaint with the District Court for the eastern district of Wisconsin petitioning the Court to declare the Statute unconstitutional because it infringed or impinged upon his Constitutional right to marry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General, is the Statute still operative?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes it is Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about this new Legislation?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Assembly Bill 100 was passed by both Houses last Friday, it is now on the Governor's desk for signature.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well if he signs it, it becomes law?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then what happens to this case?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Nothing.
The legislature has preserved the Statute in question here 245.10 intact, of course its operation has been suspended by the injunction of the Three-Judge Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean the new legislation does not affect the Statute before us?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.
In our belief it does not.
Let me explain further Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does Mr. Redhail still want to marry the girl?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: We do not know whether his ardor has cooled or not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: She has not married in the mean time?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: He has not applied for a license.
He did not apply for a license up to the time of the appeal to this Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there is something in the record that indicates he has had a second child?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: No there is not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You are going to tell me Mr. Attorney General --

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Assembly Bill 100 which is now before the Governor for signature, retains the present Statute intact.
Its operation is suspended, when there is any injunction in joining the enforcement procedures under 245.10.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has it been raised in this case?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: It was -- it is tailor-made legislation to accommodate this appeal.
If this Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well as I understand if that Statute becomes, when the Governor signs it, that automatically since there is an outstanding injunction here, suspends the operation of the Statute we have before us?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: As long as there is an injunction pending restraining the enforcement of that Statute an another Statute comes into play that slightly modifies the Statute under question.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let me approach you from the other side.
If the Statute which is now on the Governor's desk had been in effect at the time this case arose, would there be any case?
That is what I think we are trying to prove that.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I believe because of the accommodation in the new Statute to give the Court greater discretion, in terms of people who have never been married before that the Statute -- that there would be no -- that Mr. Redhail would not have been a suitable representative, plaintiff.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But he still would have had to seek the approval of the Court?
If the new Statute had been in effect, this new Statute we are talking about it, had been in effect then, he would still have to goto the Court, would he?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Not Mr. Redhail.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well then we come to what, we have been trying to get at. Is there a case left here, if the new Statute is signed by the Governor tomorrow or the next day?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes Mr. Chief Justice in that, that Statute is only operative when there is a restraining order against the enforcement of the present Statute --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And there is a restraining order.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: By the Three-Judge Court, District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin, yes --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then, the new Statute becomes operative which means Mr. Redhail then can get married without applying to a Court for permission to get married.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Redhail could have gotten married as soon as the Court issued its injunction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if this Court were to reverse the judgment of the District Court, then the new Statute would be inoperative.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, that is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You are talking about the sub-section 8 on page 4 of this Supplemental Memorandum of the Appellees, is the provision of the Statute to which your are referring I think.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I do not understand why this case has to moved now?
All he has to do is to apply for a marriage license.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: He could have applied for a marriage license under the restraining order.
We are restrained now from enforcing 245.10.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He could have been married and divorced and remarried by now could he not?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Because of the restraining order issued by the District Court, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What do we have, what is he complaining about now?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: We have a class action that embraces all people.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So can all of them, register now?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: They all could because of the restraining order under the Statute, that might become operative, they would have to -- if they have been divorced they would have to go to a Court for permission to remarry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the Statute kind of a second line of defense to the State?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, the legislature wanted to keep the Statute that is now on appeal here, the decision regarding the Statute intact.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If possible.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: In the mean time, if possible, in the mean time they have enacted this interim Statute.
If this Court affirms the restraining order of the Three-Judge Court, the new Statute will be in effect and for all practical purposes the present Statute is dead.
But should this Court lift the restraining order of the Three-Judge Court, the Statute that we are talking about immediately springs back into life.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In other words if we reverse and sustain the Constitutionality of the old Statute, the new Statute then becomes inoperative.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct and the old Statute springs --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So we have to got to decide the cases is what you are telling?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well I am suggesting that it is not moot that the legislature --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you would agreed it would [Laughter]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr Johnson let me go back to question, you indicated there was nothing on the record that implied they had a second child.

In the plaintiff or in the complaint, it is alleged that he was adjudged to be the father of a baby girl born in 1970 and I also read plaintiff desires to marry he and the woman he intends to marry are expecting a child to be born to them in early March 1975.
My question is was that child ever born?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I do not know.

So, Mr. Redhail filed a complaint with the District Court and at this point I would point out that he did not go to a judge to seek permission to remarry and counsel for the plaintiff have made a great point of a fact that the statute permits a judge to grant permission when he finds that the child of the non-custodial parent is a public charge or likely to become a public charge.
Mr. Redhail felt that apparently that he could never meet the test required by or likely to become a public charge.
This phrase has been construed by Wisconsin Court.
If construed very narrowly I would suggest that it could be acquainted with a settling of accounts up-to-date.
It is on the basis of this that we have suggested perhaps the District Court might have abstained as suggested in Reetz versus Bozanich and subsequent cases under that doctrine.
Now the Three-Judge Court decided that this should be a class action carefully noting in their decision that we have two classes really of plaintiffs.
One the named plaintiff who had never been married before and the other category would be people who had been married before and were divorced.
They also found and certified as a class all of the county clerks of the State of Wisconsin.
We have 72 County clerks, the class is very easily identifiable.
We objected an oral argument as noted in the Court's decision to certifying such a class without notification to the 71 other county clerks.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr Johnson could I go back one point that -- you said that the reason that perhaps the Court could have abstained was that the likely to become a public charge language might or might not apply, but is not the child now a public charge?
Did not the District Court find that?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: There was no determination on this particular case as whether the child was a public charge, but the child was an AFDC recipient and there is no question that Mr. Redhail would not have obtained judicial permission to remarry because of the AFDC benefits being extended to --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then he would not have any occasion to worry about the likely to become a public charge language?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I do not know we are speculating about the future but --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The matter as to this particular litigant.
We know that he could not have gotten the approval.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Not without paying up the arrearages --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But even if he payed the arrearage the child would still be a public charge.
Is not that true?
As long as she is receiving a $109 a month, from AFDC.
I just want to be sure I understand your argue.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Okay, but it is possible that had he paid up his arrearages and showed his ability to meet the support order, that he would have secured judicial permission to marry --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even though the child was still on AFDC?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: If he was on AFDC, no.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Alright and she is on AFDC.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: She was at the time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But presumably if he went into Court and showed that he had a job making $900 a month and paid up the arrearages and the child was off of welfare, then you suggest the permission would have been granted?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I think so.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Does it make the difference under your statute whether the child is in the father's custody?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes it is the --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: The statute says so, the rationale I suppose Justice Blackmum being that the custodial parent already has a burden of the care and has the right to expect contribution from the non-custodial parent.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I know the child maybe on welfare, even when she is in the father's custody, could not she?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Sure.
We are not suggesting that the law is absolutely perfect and there are no gaps, loopholes, whatever you want to call them.
We do the best we can in terms of a standard for marriage requirements.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well it certainly is not perfect it did.
I suppose there is as much risk to the State of Wisconsin for a -- to allow a marriage of a childless indigent there is to one who has a child.
The child indigent introduced to.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well.
Lets look at --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Presumably

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Presumably, but at least here we have a record to go on.
Whereas we do not have an case --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is why I was trying to help you out wondering whether there was a second one that he spawned.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: We do not know.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would not a judge -- in this case if there is another child about to be born illegitimately and this man wants to marry the girl, in order to give that child meaning, the judge would not give him that permission?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I do not know.
If I were to predict.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I would say that the judge would probably stick by the statute and refuse.
But that is just my prediction --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the State of Wisconsin public policy is, it is better to have two illegitimate children than one.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: The policy is that we are not going to condone by a piece of paper called a marriage license.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do not condone it, you will compel it.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: So, that is one of the weaknesses of the Statute.
But there is something that could be said on the other side too and I guess that is why I am here.
Alright the Three-Judge Court then certified a class action for all of the named defendants, at oral argument we objected on the basis of no notice to them.
The Courts, the Circuit Courts are split on this one following the ironclad rule given orders.
The other Circuit saying well if there is adequate representation, the notice can be dispensed with.
Now that the judge, Three-Judge Court said this Statute of Wisconsin impinges upon a fundamental right.

Right to marry and that, this requirement of going to the judge and getting permission to remarry impinges upon that fundamental right and it's therefore suspect statute and follows that the State must show a compelling State interest to sustain its validity and we object on this appeal to the application of this stringent result oriented type of test.

I think it was back in United States V. Carolene Products where a footnote by the writer of that opinion indicated that statutes are entitled to a strong presumption of constitutionality except perhaps where there is a right expressly set forth in the constitution itself.

This idea of course is grown and combinated as we pointed out in Shapiro V. Thompson in 1969 when the Court found that the right to travel, and of course it was in connection with welfare benefits was a fundamental right and the State had to show some compelling State interest that would over ride this impingement or this entitlement to exercise the fundamental right.

Since that time that case, the Boddie case on right to divorce, the Griswold case have all been cited in terms of their language to suggest this familial privacy right and to suggest that anything that touches upon the marriage the right to marriage all of its collateral attributes is suspect and subject to this test.
Though we note that in the Iowa case regarding the durational residency requirement of Iowa, Shapiro versus Thompson Doctrine of compelling State interest was not applied.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does Wisconsin recognize common law marriages?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: It does not.

Now Justice Harlan in his decent in Shapiro pointed out the danger of labeling something as a fundamental right which invokes this as we call it result oriented test, stringent test that the State must show a compelling State interest to override the impingement.
I would suggest --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Shapiro held that not that the right of Interstate travel is a constitutional right, constitutional protected right.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that was emphasized in the concurring opinion that it was more than just a subjective view of this Court that it was a fundamental right, but held rather that it was a right of Interstate travel as contrasted with international travel is constitutionally protected freedom.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Okay, expressed in the constitution, I presume.
But now we are talking about rights that are not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Expressly contained in the constitution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: And I think it is a fundamental right that a youngster should be supported by his parents.
We talk about rights, we have duties.
The right to get married, procreate has an attendant duty to support children of that marriage.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But how does the refusal, if he remarries you still cannot get the money out him, can you not?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: True, there are other laws with respect to the AFDC --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How does the refusal to get -- to permit him to marry, get the money to the child?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: It requires him to square up accounts, to pay the arrearages.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Before he gets married.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean how does that make him do it?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: It makes him do it.
We had resolution from enumerable county boards requesting us to take this appeal.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I still do not understand, you can still -- how do you collect the money, you can sue him, right in Wisconsin how do you collect this money?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well if he is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The support money how do you collect it?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Alright the county -- the clerk of the Court collects the money in an ordinary case.
A divorce case or a support case.
Clerk of the Court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And how does his marring prevent the clerk from doing that.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Listen to my question.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How does they preventing him from marrying, prevent the clerk no -- how would his marrying prevent the clerk from collecting the money?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the actual fact of his marrying, remarrying or marrying would not prevent the clerk from collecting the money, but it puts pressure on him to bring himself up-to-date with the respect to arrearages.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It saves the clerk from going through the motion.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the clerk does not -- the clerk just receives the money, he does not enforce support obligations.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well who does?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: The custodial parent.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought you said the clerk did.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: You asked me how does the money mechanically gotten to the child --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But here is a man who says I will not give my child a nickel, now what does the State of Wisconsin do to get the nickel?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Where it is willful, they can press criminal charges.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And they can do that whether he gets married or not?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: That is true.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What other way can they do it?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Contempt powers?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: The private person can bring an action for contempt.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And he can do that, he can do that after his marriage too can he not?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes he can.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So what good is it stopping him from marrying?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: The pressure it puts upon him.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Moral.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Moral.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is all.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: To square accounts.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is that all?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well it does prevent him from undertaking another legal obligation.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: And incurring further obligation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He has already incurred one did not you say illegitimate child coming along.
Well he has already incurred that.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Okay, and before he incurs further let us have him face up to the responsibility that he has already acquired.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but at least the complaint says he has already incurred a second one.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Well.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So what does your statute do?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: For Mr. Redhail it does not seem to do very much, but down the line somewhere, he is going to be called to square accounts if he wants that piece of paper from State of Wisconsin saying, hey we condone your marriage.
In conclusion, I would just point out that in its domestic relation policy, the State of Wisconsin has attempted to affect a higher standard of conduct than is normally been expected.

We have been shot down by the Three-Judge Court who failed -- which failed to balance the interest of the custodial spouse, the interest of the child, the protection of the child and I point out that the purpose of this statute is annunciated by our Supreme Court State of Wisconsin Supreme Court and State (Inaudible) is to protect the child and protect the integrity of the marital relationship, that is all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Johnson.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me ask just one question which marital relationship is it protecting, there was no marital relationship at all here, was there?

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Down the line it is perhaps a deter, that you cannot walk out a family and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that is to protect the integrity of the preexisting marriage if there was one.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Blondis.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
The defendants have not denied that marriage involves a fundamental right, the source of the right is found, not in State law, but in our intrinsic human race.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Blondis before you get into your legal argument, the Judgment of the District Court, I guess was entered in the Spring of 75.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: No stay was entered.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did your client go ahead and get married?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, our client got married Illinois before the injunction was entered by the Court.
A substantial period of time, the lapse between the time, but the class was ordered maintainable as a class action as to the plaintiffs.
Till then oral argument was held and then lastly the opinion was rendered and the order for judgment -- and judgment were rendered.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did you call the attention of the District Court the fact that your client has gotten married Illinois?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: At that we could not get a hold of our client, Your Honor.
We were not aware that he got married in Illinois.
The Illinois marriage is invalid and he is still affected by section 245.10.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It maybe invalid by the Wisconsin statute.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You don't challenge that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: We had not at that time, he got married after all the pleadings, after the case had been completely submitted to the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I don't understand -- I am just curious, I guess it is not here, but here you have got a statute, Wisconsin statute, that is proposed to be operative on an Illinois marriage.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Well, Mr. Redhail was a resident of Wisconsin when he went in seeking.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, So, So?
While he --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: The constitutionality of that provision [Laughter] maybe questionable Your Honor.
It had not when Mr. Redhail came into our office, he was not being affected by that statute.
He kind of cared less about the statute.
He wanted to get married.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is he still a resident of Wisconsin.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, he is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did he ever tell the Judge?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Did he ever?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Ever tell the Trial Judge that he was a married man when he was asking for permission to get married.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
He and his --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, do you think that is proper?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: He and his intended --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you think that it is proper, to mislead a Judge?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, he never was in fact married.
His marriage was invalid.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well did he tell him that he had invalidly married?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: The Federal Judge?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No, he did not.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But do not you think he should have?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: In light of the fact Your honor that his marital status was the same as if he had never got married in Wisconsin --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did he get married in Illinois?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: He got married in Illinois because he was having a second child by his intended spouse, had been refused permission by the State to receive permission to marry, sought desperately to get married and I have not discussed with him his exact reason for getting married, but it could have been that he just simply got impatient.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But, do not you --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Went into Illinois --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But with all of this imagination, do not you think, it was your duty as a lawyer and a member of the Bar to give the Judge the true facts of the case that you are representing to him the truth.
The whole truth.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, we were not aware that he had gotten married until after the opinion and injunction.
In other words we lost touch with Mr. Redhail.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well did you think, then you should tell the Judge?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, no we did not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was the child born?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I take it then that the marriage, that the formalization of the marriage, of the blessing by the State must have meant something to Mr. Redhail.
As he was willing to go down to Illinois and get there.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: To Mr. Redhail, it did.
We have since explained the legal predicament that he has put himself in.
For whatever reason the solemnization of his relationship which in fact is void under the eyes of Wisconsin law.
Did mean something to him and his spouse.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I still do not understand why would you-- why you say so readily that the marriage is void.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Because Wisconsin-- Under the, under the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Wisconsin law stays another State marriage.
You do not suppose as any questions about that.
I suppose it was just a matter of age under Wisconsin law.
Male can not marry before he is 21.
he happen to be 19.
But, the age in Illinois was 18.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I believe that under Wisconsin law, Wisconsin law, even in the age requirement is that if one leaves the State for the purpose of intentionally awaiting its State's marriage laws, then returns to the State and retains residency.
That law or that marriage is invalid and would have to be validated.
In Mr. Redhail's case, Mr. Redhail would have to go through an annulment proceedings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Was this, one of those overnight trips to Waukegan?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.
From what I understand.[Laughter]

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Blondis, what worries me is, you spending so much time trying to make your client's child illegitimate.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, I am --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you know what you are doing?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No.
I am trying to have a loss --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if you make the marriage invalid, the child would be illegitimate.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor, I did not make the marriage invalid.
The statute in question, section 245.10.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you are spending a whole lot of time now trying.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Well, I am trying to persuade the Court that the statute is invalid and that Mr. Redhail has been victimized by the statute.
Not only has he been victimized by the statute, but his indented spouse has been victimized by the statute and his second child has been victimized by the statute.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, as legal predicament with respect to the present -- to his additional marriage, Illinois is not going to be affected whether he win or lose this case.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Oh, yes it will your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why is that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: If he -- if this statute, if this Court affirms the Lower Court, Mr. Redhail would then --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, he can get a license.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know but, just wining this case is not going to validate the marriage. Is not going to --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No.
He would then have to undergo a State Court proceeding which has absolutely nothing to do with the question in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why is that Mr. Blondis?
If the statute is invalid, it is no longer, presents any impediment to the validity of the Illinois marriage.
But, that --
That --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: The Illinois marriage complicates things because in -- I do not believe it complicates things for purposes of this case.
It complicates things for Mr. Redhail because he would have to Your Honor, under Wisconsin law, there is no such thing as a void marriage.
That is in order for a marriage to be clear --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that surely is going to paragraph five of the statute and the marriage --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: But, even then he would have to go through a Court procedure so that a Judge says that it is void.
In other words, it maybe void in fact, but a Court has to announce that it is void.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, but if we hold the statute unconstitutional, there is no basis for holding it void and the marriage would be good.
I do not understand why the marriage can be bad is the statute is bad.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Oh, I see your point.
Yes, I think I --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is provision, that provision just is not an issue here.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is right, that is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You see there are other provisions in the statute.

Yes, that is right, because it says any marriage in fact without compliance with this section, without compliance if we hold the section which needs to be complied was invalid there is no non-compliance.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct, as long as 245 is on books, in Wisconsin, then Mr. Redhail's marriage is as if he never got married.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But, 245 was never a tact on that grounds in the District Court.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: The extra-territorial affect of it.
That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is the second child living with Redhail now?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: To my knowledge Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is the woman that he purported to marry in Illinois living with him.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Blondis, the class certification was on February 20 on the 1975 as I understand it.
Is a marriage before or after that.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Afterwards Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So, the class had been certified before the Illinois marriage took place.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, class.
Yes, that is right and after, well after all argument had taken place.

Your Honor, the State in its brief proposed to this Court that because that this is a statute dealing with marriage and divorce, the State has peculiar interest in that area and therefore this Court should supply a rational relationship, equal protection or I suppose, substantive Due Process analysis to this case.

The State in my opinion gave no good reason why that should be the case, we are aware of cases both in marriage and divorce and in voting and probate where this Court has held that States have a peculiar interest in those areas, but we do not believe that the Court has ever gone so far as to hold that regulations which adversely effect serious long standing fundamental, constitutional rights are going to be completely deferred to by the State by the application of the rational relationship equal protection test.
Concerning the purposes of the statute, the State argued in the Lower Court that the purposes of the statute was the provision of counseling to persons who are about to go -- undergo marriage.

I bring that up, only because the only legislative history available in behind the statute which is cited at pages 29 through 32 of our brief indicates that, that in fact was the benevolent purpose of the statute.
It was to provide counseling for persons who had support obligations and were about to undergo marriage.
This statute obviously has nothing to do with counseling.
Counseling is not even mentioned in the confines of the statute.
Courts are not encouraged or mandated to give counseling, nor are applicants to the Courts encouraged to get it.
So, if counseling is still the purpose of the statute, it is completely irrational.
The reason most seriously forward by the State, presently in this appeal is that this statute protects the interests that Mr. Redhail's child has to support.
We do not believe that either is the intent of the statute Mr. Redhail's child has been supported by under the AFDC program almost since her birth that is if the first child.
The debt that Mr. Redhail owes is not to that child, the debt that he owes is to the State of Wisconsin.
What Wisconsin is saying in affect to Mr. Redhail is that until you pay us you can not get married

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean that father has no responsibility?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I am not, no Your Honor, I am not saying that at all.
Mr. Redhail went to paternity Court in 1972.
He admitted paternity in that action and the Court ordered that he pay support of $109 per month.

That although as the State agreed he was a minor and a high school student, well in any event the AFDC which he received -- which his child is receiving is substantially above $109 per month, that he was ordered to pay.

Therefore what I am saying is that even if Mr. Redhail tomorrow came into the clerk of Court with all of his arrearages under that $109 support order and paid every cent of that even pay the $109 sometime into the future.
He still could not get married because his child would still be count – would still remain a public charge.
So, how the State can justify the statute by saying that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it not up to the State to justify the statute is it?
The State has enacted the statute and it is presentively constitutionally valid.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I understand that Your Honor but what am I saying is that what I just said indicates that it really does not have much to do with its intended purpose.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well then why -- then the State should not put support orders in at all?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you know what you are arguing?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No not at all --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Because you say that 109 does not do any good.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: It would not do Mr. Redhail any good, it would do the child a lot of good.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well that is what I thought we would do the child some good.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That is what the State is saying.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: But what am I saying is that statute is not -- this particular statute is not related to child support.
If the State is serious about collecting child support from Mr. Redhail the State has many methods available to it which are very effective.
The State can take Mr. Redhail back in that paternity Court which originally set the $109 per month support and that State can say Mr. Redhail you tell the Court why you have not paid the $109.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What you are telling us that State could have enacted some other legislation.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: State has --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it did enact this legislature and the question is it constitutionally valid?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, but the reason I make that point, the point that there is legislation which, there is other legislation available to it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well that is always true with any law.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Is that is -- it is my understanding under the either the substantive Due process or the Equal Protection strict scrutiny analysis, that the last prong of that analysis, is that there must be a showing not that there is a compelling State interest and that the legislation is tied to that interest.
But that there is no last intrusive method available for the State to accomplish its legitimate goal.
In accomplishing presuming that this accomplishes the State goal in coercing somehow Mr. Redhail to pay support.
It also takes away his fiancee's right to marry, it absolutely prohibits her from marrying.
Mr. Redhail's case --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well marrying him.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Marrying him yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There are 230 million or I guess 115 million people; males in United States.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: But she was adamant that she wanted to marry him.[Laughter]
It also has has the effect on Mr. Redhail's case of stigmatizing his second child as an illegitimate child.
So the statute not only affects Mr. Redhail, it also affects many other person.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about most if not all State have laws that a tell a man how is married to somebody else that he can not get married because he is married to somebody else.

This I suppose does not in fact prohibit him from impregnating some other female, you think that such a State law would be unconstitutional just because particularly as it affects somebody how has made some other woman pregnant.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No Your Honor, I think this statute is unique to Wisconsin I think that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well then why does not your argument run the -- make equally invalid bigamy law.
I said was a disqualification not a criminal thing --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: In the offer decision that this Court decided last term the Court again reiterated that the right to marry is a fundamental right and Stated that the right again is not a source of State law, but is basic human right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But what if a man wants to marry his sister and the State says you can not do it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I am getting to that Your Honor.

The Court held that the right to marry is contoured in our society and in our traditions and I think that no one would argue that the tradition of marriage as this society knows it, would prohibit a person either from having two wives at one time or two husbands at one time for that matter or marrying his sister.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is only because of statutory laws is in it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, but the statute reflects the history and traditions of the fundamental right to marry and this compelling a person or prohibiting a person from marrying because his children are receiving public assistance.
I do not believe is a part of that fundamental or of that tradition as we know the right to marry --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you making kind of a natural law argument to us, Judeo-Christian morality.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No, Your Honor all I am saying as far as the language in the offer opinion is language of this Court and language noting -- that the Court, that the right to marriage is in fact older that the bill of rights.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say that legislature can only enact the thing that you regard as traditional onto the notions of marriage.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Well Your Honor, I do not believe that the –- presuming that there was legislation which seriously prohibited the right to marry and let us say that, that legislation was an age limitation.

I believe that, that type of limitation would be justifiable both because the State could show a very strong interest in it and because it has traditionally been a part of State's role to define an age limit before which one can marry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You say justifiable, you suggest the State has to justify that legislation?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Well I do not -- I think -- I do not want to get into Semantics, I think that which either side is trying to justify it, there are some prohibitions and marriage that can certainly be justified and I that there are others that can not.
The point that I would stress is that Court does not have to decide in this case every justification or non-justification for concerning the interference on the right to marry.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But it has to lay down some principal reason for ruling in your favor if it does so and I take your suggestion that some principal reason can be laid down that would not also invalidate bigamy statute, well what is it?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I believe Your Honor that the Court in these kinds of cases has considered each, each prohibition or interval has weighed each marriage, divorce law that it has been dealing with and its own individual merits in this case --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well how does it determine its own individual merits issue, but I thought that was with the legislature.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Alright.
We start from the analysis that marriage is fundamental right.
A fundamental right, a fundamental constitutional right and that I think that Court has reiterated that in numerous cases.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is that fundamental right for a person 12 years old?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now when the State passes this statute saying that they can not marry under the age of 18 is not one of the reason attributable to the legislature that most people under 18 are not able to support wives and children.
Is that not one of the consideration of the legislature?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I am not sure, but it very well may be Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Was not that not that a reasonable one?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Which could be attributed to the legislature.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: But Your Honor this statute does not even have that kind of a justification.

In order to justify , in order to justify this statute on those ground one would assume, one would have to assume that by entering into a marriage a person is becoming less able to support a prior child.

With a number of childless new marriages today and the number of households in which both spouses work there is entirely possible that by entering into a marriage one could actually improve ones ability to support a child from a former marriage or a child who was born out of marriage.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well that is a good argument to advance to a Legislature, but it does not carry much weight as far as I am concerned.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How about your client.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor in our --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In that respect, I am not -- it might be true a lot of other people, but you are entitled to raise that unless you have some concrete objection on this regard.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Well, Your Honor the class was defined to cover everyone who was affected by the Statute and the class was not defined on the basis of indigence versus non-indigence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well does the other side object to the class of designation.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: It has no -- it has never objected to the definition of the class.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So are you think you can raise the problems of the indigent even though you petitioner, your client might be wealthy.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: In this case it would be exactly the opposite.
But the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well so you say your client is indigent or no.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, and I --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is all I really wanted to know.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes, there is a stipulation of fact in the record that, during all times that are relevant to the Litigation Mr. Redhail was indigent was unemployed and for a good deal of that time was a high school student.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And not capable of supporting this child.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Blondis are you going to come at the new Statute.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor I believe that the appellant's summary of the new Statute is fairly accurate.
If Mr. -- in addition to making some exceptions that are not found in the present Statute.
Mr. Redhail would not be covered at all by the new Statute, because it only covers support obligations which were entered into as a result of a marriage.
It does not cover out of wedlock children and I would hope that it might indicate suspicion on the part of the State Legislature as to some of the problems with the Wisconsin Statute

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you agree with him that if we reverse the Lower Court here and sustain the Statute the new statute Statute becomes -- is not applicable.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Unless -- unless another Court -- the Legislation does not specifically refer to this case.
The Legislation says that the new section will go into affect if any Court stays or enjoins 245.10 which is the present Statute.

We made after submitting the supplemental memorandum to this Court made as much of an investigation as we could and to our knowledge there is no Litigation either pending or already decided, which would have that effect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Blondis may we ask you and the Attorney of General both to let us know forthwith when the Governor moves on the bill that is pending on his desk.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Most certainly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that we know whether it is approved.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there an over right provision in Wisconsin.
If it is veto.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: It wont be -- my understanding is that will not be veto, yes there is an over right provision.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You might consider also if you -- excuse me Mr. Justice Marshall.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Go on.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Submitting a memorandum each of you on the impact Statute.
Now Justice Marshall's Question.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What I was wondering is the Statute -- I do not know (Inaudible) is peculiar to me as to any other Statute in Wisconsin is a normal procedure to present Statute that are limited to the Court decision and say so in this Statute.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: This is the first time that I have seen this Wisconsin Your Honor.
I understand that has happed in some other States.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Blondis does the record tell us anything about the financial circumstances of the wife of the plaintiff, the present wife.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: No Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that even if had alleged that she was a very wealthy person it would have enabled him to discharge the support obligation.
He still could have married her.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct Your Honor.

Mr. Redhail could -- Mr. Redhail I would like to emphasize again under this statute for all intends can never get married unless the custodian of his first child gets off of welfare and that is completely beyond his control.
So --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If a child becomes a multimillionaire I think it will be --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes because then the child would no longer receive welfare, but again the child becoming a multimillionaire is probably beyond his control.
Just a few comments concerning the abstention argument.

The defendants did not even seriously forward the abstention argument in the Lower Court and this Court has noted in a number of opinions that it will take that into consideration in determining whether abstention applies.

It is our opinion that abstention does not apply in any of its forms, the defendants argued that the Pullman Doctrine applies because the statute is constitutionally unclear, but it is our understanding of the Pullman Doctrine, that it only applies when the statue itself is unclear.
Concerning notice to the class of defendants the Trial Court noted in its opinion that there was as much unity of interest among those defendants as possibly there could have been.
Every defendant --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why did you want a defendants class?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why did you want a class of defendants here?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Because Mr. Redhail could not have received permission in any county in the State of Wisconsin because each defendant in the State, each defendant which is every county clerk in the State of Wisconsin has exactly the same obligations on statute --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but surely it is a Court decision affecting one would be honored by every other county clerk in the State, would it not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I would hope so Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well and he only wants one marriage license, does he not?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct but --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So why does he need 72 county clerks to be enjoined?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: At the time that the action was brought --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This is a class action, Mr. Blondis?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: The real answer is that, if the action is a class action as to State wide class of plaintiffs.
All of those plaintiffs are not going to be applying to the Milwaukee County Court clerk Mr. Zablocki.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Did you allege that even one -- every county was represented?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you have a member of your class in every county.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do you allege that?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Every member of the plaintiff class.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I am not sure that it is --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well if you do not, then I see why you need every county clerk?

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: I would --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Right.
That problem is unanswered --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That problem is unanswered.

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: In any event I would hope that were this Court should affirm the other members of the class of the defendant class would abide by the Court's decision.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why is everybody is so eager to get class actions going on both side of the case. Is this the Law School Theory these days or what is it?[Laughter]

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: Your Honor in my Law School we did not study class actions.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well is it not a fact in Wisconsin that during the abortions litigation they ignore the orders in certain districts and then they had to do it class action.
In the State of Wisconsin --

turn.speaker: robert_h_blondis
turn.label: Mr. Robert H. Blondis
turn.text: There is some problem in that litigation with non-class action and enforcement of Federal Court orders.
Thank you.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Ward L. Johnson, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. Johnson do you think in your two remaining minutes there is anything you can do to help clarify this.

turn.speaker: ward_l_johnson_jr
turn.label: Mr. Ward L. Johnson, Jr.
turn.text: I will along with counsel for the appellee submit a memorandum, with respect to the new law, which the governor we expect will sign and I will ask any question in remaining two minutes that any --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I hear none, thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
